title: Assignment 1 Instructions
section: Step 0: Choose one or two Visualizations to Recreate
text:
Step 0: Choose one or two Visualizations to Recreate

Browse the set of provided visualizations and datasets
  
.Each vis is accompanied by the dataset used to create it. Select one or two visualizations to attempt to recreate.

Familiarize yourself with the dataset and its structure. Do some exploring on the Data to Viz 
  
 site to learn common vis names, caveats, and some tips to create them. As a hint, I have put the chart name in brackets for each image (though sometimes names will differ!)

Decide whether you will use AI or not ‚Äì if you use it, be sure to include the link in your submission

title: Assignment 1 Instructions
section: Step 1: Recreate Visualization #1 with your chosen tool
text:
Step 1: Recreate Visualization #1 with your chosen tool

Choose an appropriate tool from the list of approved tools, based on the dataset and visualization type. You can change your mind at any time.

Load and prepare the dataset.






Note



The dataset may require preprocessing (e.g., filtering, cleaning, or restructuring) to match the visual representation in the original image. You should document any changes you make to the dataset to recreate the visualization. You can add auxiliary data as needed, but don‚Äôt forget to cite and document it!








TipFAQs




 Do we have to write code to stream the data from the Google Docs link? 



Write some code to recreate the visualization(s) as accurately as you can






TipFAQs




 Do I need to try and replicate even the little icons and shapes? 
 Do we have to match the colors too? 
 What if I can‚Äôt get an exact 1:1 replica?



Write a step-by-step breakdown of how you created each visualization (for eample, any data cleaning or transformation required, how to change the formatting to match the original, how to add text and/or annotations, etc.).
You can do this by choosing one or more of these options:

(preferred option) Interspersing markdown cells with your code cells in notebook environments, such as Colab, Jupyter, Observable, R, Matlab. Also export to .pdf if possible.

Use Quarto to intersperse text and code (node you‚Äôll still need to upload the runnable code)

Including block comments in your code, and line comments as well (ok option, but gets hard to read fast)

Screenshotting code snippets and putting them into a word doc interspersed with text (not recommended, but you do you)

Narrating a screen-capture video of you writing the code while explaining what you‚Äôre doing. Be sure to include closed captions/subtitles (great choice if you don‚Äôt like fiddling with documents)

Your documentation should be clear enough that another student could follow your steps and recreate your visualization without prior knowledge of the data or tool.






TipFAQs




 If I choose the video option, can I use AI to generate the narration? 
 How beautiful does my code need to be?

title: Assignment 1 Instructions
section: Step 2: Add a descriptive caption to your vis
text:
Step 2: Add a descriptive caption to your vis
Add a caption summarizing the visualization‚Äôs purpose and encodings. Check out this resource 
  
 for how to write great captions.

Some vis tools have built-in functionality for creating captions, others don‚Äôt. If you choose a tool that doesn‚Äôt, find a workaround, and then you can mention how annoying it was to have to do that in your reflection üòÄ.







Note



Captions are more than just titles! They should be able to stand alone if taken out of context, succinctly describing the main points the viewer should take away from looking at this image: What is being shown? What are the salient features? What task or analysis question can be completed or addressed by this vis?

Step 3: Reflection






Important



Please type in the Google Assignent doc provided on Blackboard, don‚Äôt copy paste from another doc, or it will get flagged as plagiarism by the system! Also pls no AI


As you‚Äôre working, take some time to reflect and write some short notes about:

Which tools did you consider, and which did you end up choosing to use, and why?

What challenges did you encounter in replicating the visualization?

Did you have to modify the dataset in any way to get the desired output?

Which features of your tool helped or hindered the recreation process (strengths/limitations)?

Are there elements of the original visualization that were difficult or impossible to replicate? If so, why?

What is one piece of advice you would give someone wanting to use this tool?

If you had to do this again, would you choose the same tool? Why or why not?

Write your reflection via Blackboard under Assignment 1 Part 2, then don‚Äôt forget to press ‚ú®Submit ‚ú®






TipFAQs




 Are bullets fine for my reflection, or do you want a full essay?

title: Assignment 1 Instructions
text:
Frequently Asked Questions






NoteDo we have to write code to stream the data from the Google Docs link?





No! Feel free to do whatever causes less friction. If using a notebook, you can drag the data into your runtime, but note it will disappear at the end of each session, unless you connect it to a static cloud source. If you‚Äôre writing code locally, feel free to download the data and then read in with any read function (Pandas can be great for this in Python)









NoteHow beautiful does my code need to be?





Not pristine, just readable. Please dont pass it thruugh AI though, as that may cause the system to flag for verbatim text









NoteWhat if I can‚Äôt get an exact 1:1 replica?





Try and get as close as you can, and then in your reflection you can talk about how yours differs from the original, what elements of the original you were unable to figure out how to do, why, and propose a solution if you had more time.









NoteDo we have to match the colors too?





Yes! Get as close as you can. If you want to be precise about the colors, use this color picker! However, don‚Äôt worry about things like complicated background gradients.









NoteDo I need to try and replicate even the little icons and shapes?





If the vis has fancy little icons or weird shapes, you can omit those. For example, the little people icons in this bar chart‚Äôs legend (however, you should still include the legend!)









NoteAre bullets fine for my reflection, or do you want a full essay?





Bullets are fine as long as I can understand your experience, and it‚Äôs clear which question you‚Äôre answering. If two questions tie together you may want to change the ordering, group questions, etc. for better flow Also feel free to write it as standard prose or train of thought, whatever you prefer!









NoteCan I use AI to generate the narration?





Sure, but you‚Äôd then need to write a script in your own words, and at that point why not just write it down? I guess you could do voice to text back to AI voice‚Ä¶sounds complicated, but up to you. Don‚Äôt forget the closed captions also!









NoteWhat if I want/need to use a different format?





Shoot me a message and we‚Äôll figure it out!

text:
1. Identify the domain (subject area)
Use an appropriate amount of specificity.









Tip‚úÖ Good examples of domains




Explainable AI
Healthcare economics
Social network analysis











Warning‚ùåBad examples of domains




Machine Learning (too broad)
Minor 7th dominant cords in Bach symphonies (too specific)
Data visualization (too meta)

title: Phase 0: Individual Project Pitch
section: 2. Describe a target user of your vis
text:
2. Describe a target user of your vis
Use objective observables to describe them that relate to the task (check Chapter 3).









Tip‚úÖ Good examples of users




Consumer with a fitness tracker
A potential voter

Venture capitalist











Warning‚ùå Bad examples of users




Myself and/or my friends
Someone that doesn‚Äôt understand the data
The professor grading this vis

title: Phase 0: Individual Project Pitch
text:
3. Describe the main task(s)
These could be action/target pairs or analysis question(s) the user of your vis would need to do (check Chapter 3).









Tip‚úÖ Good examples of tasks




Determine how object size affects semantic segmentation boundaries
Cluster Goodreads users based on book genre and recommendations
Explore the narrative structure of popular Manga











Warning‚ùå Bad examples of tasks




To understand the data
To learn about Chemistry

title: Phase 0: Individual Project Pitch
text:
4. Identify one or more datasets
These can be exemplars; you are not locked in. Make sure the dataset is available, documented, and of good quality.









Tip‚úÖ Good examples of datasets




Bird Migration Data (data was used for a published paper, documentation exists, readable .csv format)
Cityscapes Dataset (benchmark dataset used for many CV/AI/ML papers, lots of code available on internet to process)
Iris Dataset (another canonical dataset, straight from an academic lab)











Warning‚ùå Bad examples of datasets




We will scrape Instagram (you probably won‚Äôt have time, data will be messy)
We will collect a survey about people‚Äôs habits (designing a good survey is super tricky, takes time)
We will request Twitter/X API developer access to collect Tweets (again, no time)
Anything like this: test.csv

title: Phase 0: Individual Project Pitch
section: 5. Find, link, and briefly describe related work
text:
5. Find, link, and briefly describe related work
These should be a few related visualizations you‚Äôve come across while looking into this area. You may want to consider how might a different kind of visualization reveal new insights?
Related work can be ‚Äúrelated‚Äù by being similar in the What-Why-How framework (Chapter 1,2,3) in any of these ways:






TipWays that related work can be related




Same/similar domain
Same/similar dataset type/semantics (Chapter 2)
Similar tasks & target user (Chapter 3)
Similar vis type/idiom (Chapter 5, Chapter 7, Chapter 8, Chapter 9)
Similar interaction mechanisms (Chapter 11-14)



You can use any visual you find on the internet or in print, but you must be able to trace it back to the original source and cite it.
